snippet: With children suffering from nicotine poisoning, Washington can’t just rely on the tobacco industry to police its suppliers.
abstract: Editorial warns that children as young as 7 are working in tobacco farms in North Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee and Virginia, with many suffering from symptoms of acute nicotine poisoning; cites study from Human Rights Watch painting grim picture of child labor in United States, and calls for changes to child labor laws that allow hazardous agricultural work.
lead_paragraph: With children suffering from nicotine poisoning, Washington can’t just rely on the tobacco industry to police its suppliers.

headline.main: Children Don’t Belong in Tobacco Fields
